sense.name: prediction or forecast based on observed trend
sense.commentary: PROJECTION[+action][+prediction][+evidence][+trend][+observed] Note: implies a forecast that continues the direction of an observed trend.
sense.examples: These plans are based on projections of slow but positive growth in the economy. This study's projection of global mean temperature by 2030 differs from other studies.

sense.name: a visual image cast at a distance from its source
sense.commentary: PROJECTION[+representation][+image][+visual][+cast][+remotely] Note: often implies a screen on which the image is presented.
sense.examples: The ghosts in the Haunted House were actually holographic projections. John fiddled with the projector to make the projection on the screen come into focus. The projection of shadows on the wall from the trees outside looked strangely eerie.

sense.name: a geometric perspective or transformation of an object
sense.commentary: PROJECTION[+representation][+transformation][+geometric] Note: a mathematical construct where certain geometric properties are transformed
sense.examples: In a Mercator map projection, Greenland is distorted spatially to appear larger than it is. Points are geometric properties that are invariant under projection. This map is a type of conic projection.

sense.name: a planned or intentional promotion or presentation
sense.examples: They disdain the legal profession's projection of itself as a force of altruism. The candidate's projection of himself as a regular guy didn't persuade some voters.

sense.name: psychological process of attributing one's own traits to someone or something external
sense.examples: Mary suffered from her mother's projections of guilt and blame on to her. John's therapist helped him realize his projection of hostility on the people around him. These drawings of monsters are projections of the child's fears. (extended usage)

sense.name: a physical shape or form that juts out
sense.commentary: PROJECTION[+structure][+extension][+appendage] [+quality][+shape][+convex][+jutting] Note: the projection refers to a thing or form itself, not an activity.(Sense 8)
sense.examples: He tore his pants on a small sharp projection on bus seat. These projections of pale green are the new growth on the pine tree.

sense.name: an acoustic property such that a sound carries well
sense.examples: The projection of the voice must carry to the very back row of a theater. Her voice has sufficient projection to be heard above a Wagnerian orchestra.

sense.name: the action of extending outwards
sense.commentary: PROJECTION[+action][+extending][+outward][+thrust/+expel] Note: implies an actor or agent that initiates the projection
sense.examples: The projection of lava went high above the rim of the volcano. This dance involves the projection of the hips in a rhythmic fashion. The projection of military might was achieved through the deployment of aircraft carriers. (figurative extension)
